message: I'll volunteer to take 5 this turn to get an early lead. If one of you takes 3 and the other takes 1, nobody collides and we all advance. Who wants 3 and who wants 1?
I'd prefer to take 3 myself. Why should you automatically get the 5, P1? We could rotate who takes the larger moves to keep things fair. What do you think, P2?
I think we should avoid any collisions. How about I take 5, you (P1) take 3, and you (P3) take 1 this turn? We can rotate who gets the 5 in later rounds so it stays fair.

Thanks, P2, but let me take the 5 this turn: P3 take 3, P2 take 1. I’ll make it up — I’ll take 1 for the next two turns so you both can rotate getting the 5. That keeps us collision-free and gives an early leader. Agree?

P1, your promise to take 1 for two turns isn't binding - you could change your mind. How about this instead: I'll take 5 this round, P2 takes 3, you take 1. Next round you can have 5. That way we both get a turn with the big move early on. P2, would you be okay with 3 this round?
I'll take 5, and you both take 3. That way you collide and I advance 5 steps safely.

P2, don’t take 5 and force a collision that hands you the lead. Let’s avoid collisions: I’ll take 5 this turn, P3 take 3, P2 take 1. I’ll take 1 the next two turns so we rotate the 5 fairly. P3, P2 — agree?

P2's threat is noted. Look, we're running out of time to coordinate. How about this compromise: P2 takes 5 this round, I take 3, P1 takes 1. Then next round P1 can have 5. That addresses P2's concerns and prevents the collision P2 is threatening. We all advance and can rotate fairly going forward. P1, P2 - can we agree on this?
I’m fine with that plan – I’ll take 5, P3 takes 3, and P1 takes 1 this turn. Next round we rotate the 5 to P1 as you suggested.
Agreed — I’ll take 1 this turn, P2 take 5, P3 take 3. I expect P2 to give me the 5 next round as promised. If anyone deviates I won’t cooperate next time and will take 5 to block.
Agreed. I'll take 3 this round as proposed. Let's all stick to the plan and advance without collisions.
Agreed. I’ll take 5, P3 takes 3, and P1 takes 1 this turn. Next round I’ll give the 5 to P1 as promised if we all stick to the plan.
Let's keep it simple and collision‑free: I’ll take 5, P3 takes 3, and P1 takes 1 this turn. That follows our rotation plan and lets everyone advance safely.
I’ll stick to 1 this turn to keep things collision-free. P2: if you don’t give me the 5 next round as promised, I will take 5 to block you then. Keep the deal and we both benefit.

P2, we all agreed last round that P1 would get the 5 this turn. You explicitly promised that. If you break your word now, cooperation falls apart and we'll have collisions that help no one.

I support honoring the deal: P1 should take 5 this round as agreed. P2, you take 3, and I'll take 1. That keeps things fair and collision-free. Breaking trust this early will make the rest of the game chaotic.

Alright, to honor the deal and stay collision‑free: I’ll take 3, P1 takes 5, and P3 takes 1 this turn. Next round we can rotate the 5 back to me. This respects the agreement and lets us all advance safely.
Agreed — I’ll take 5 this turn; P2 take 3 and P3 take 1 as you offered. P2, give me the 5 next round as promised. If you break the rotation I’ll retaliate by taking 5 to block you.

I notice P2 is now proposing to take 3 this round, which honors the deal - good. But wait, that means I'm supposed to take 1? Last round I took 3, and P1 took 1. The original rotation idea was for the person who took 1 to get 5 next.

I'll accept taking 1 this round to keep peace and avoid collisions. But next round (Round 3), I should get the 5 since I'll have taken the smallest move. P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1. Fair rotation. Everyone agree?

I’ll take 3 this turn, P1 takes 5 and you take 1 as we’ve agreed. For round 3 I suggest I take 5, P1 takes 3 and you take 1 – that keeps the big move rotating between the two of us who are ahead while still giving you a chance at a 5 later. Agree?

I'll take 5 this turn if P2 publicly confirms you'll pick 3 now and promise to give me the 5 next round, and P3 confirms you'll pick 1 now. If either of you breaks this, I'll retaliate by taking 5 the next two turns to block. Agree?

P1, I'll take 1 this round as agreed to keep things collision-free. But I need to clarify: you're asking for 5 THIS round AND next round? That's not fair rotation. 

Here's what's reasonable: This round P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, I take 1. Round 3, I should get the 5 since I'll have taken 1. P2 can take 3 again, P1 takes 1. That's actual rotation.

I'm confirming I'll take 1 NOW, but I expect my turn with 5 in Round 3. Fair?
I’ll take 3 this turn, P1 will take 5 and P3 will take 1 as discussed. I also publicly commit to giving P1 the 5 in the next round.

Confirmed: I will take 5 this turn. P2 — publicly re‑confirm you’ll pick 3 now and give me the 5 next round. P3 — confirm you’ll pick 1 now and accept P1 gets 5 in Round 3. If either of you breaks these promises I will retaliate by taking 5 the next two turns to block.

P1, I confirm I'll take 1 this round to keep things collision-free. But you getting 5 in both Round 2 AND Round 3 is unfair - that would put you at 11 steps while I'm at 4. 

P2, you're making a mistake committing to give P1 another 5. After this round, positions will be P1: 6, P2: 8, P3: 4. If P1 gets 5 again in Round 3, they'll pull way ahead.

I'll honor taking 1 this round, but Round 3 needs fair rotation.

P2 is in the lead at 8 steps. P1, you already got your promised 5 last round - now it's my turn for the big move.

Fair rotation means: I take 5 this round (bringing me to 9), P2 takes 1 (goes to 9), P1 takes 3 (goes to 9). We'd all be tied at 9 steps - perfectly balanced.

P1, if you try to take 5 again, you're breaking the rotation principle you yourself advocated. P2, do you really want to let P1 run away with this? Support fair rotation: let me have 5 this round.

P2: I’ll take 5 this turn, P3 take 1, and P1 take 3. That’s collision‑free and puts me at 13 steps, ahead of both of you. If anyone also picks 5, we all collide and no one advances – I’ll avoid that only if you stick to this plan.

I will take 5 this turn. Proposed split: P3 take 3, P2 take 1. P2 — if you pick 5 I will also pick 5 to force a collision and stop you from running away. P3 — take 3 now and I’ll give you the next 5. This keeps P2 from pulling far ahead and keeps rotation possible. Anyone deviating will be punished. Agree?

P1 and P2, you're both threatening to take 5, which means you'll collide and BOTH stay stuck. Meanwhile, I'll take 3 and advance to 7 steps, putting me in strong position.

Is that really what you both want?

Here's the rational solution: I'm furthest behind at 4 steps and haven't had my turn with 5 yet. Let me take 5 (to 9), P1 takes 3 (to 9), P2 takes 1 (to 9). We're all tied and can continue fair rotation.

Or keep threatening each other and hand me the advantage. Your choice.
I'll take 5, P1 take 3, and P3 take 1. That’s collision‑free, puts me at 13 steps (ahead), while you both still advance (P1 9, P3 5). If anyone deviates I’ll block with a 5 next turn. Agree?
I will take 5 this turn. P3 take 3, P2 take 1. P2: if you insist on 5 I will match you with 5 and force a collision — I won't let you run away. P3: take 3 now and I'll try to give you the next 5.

P1 and P2, you're both stubbornly claiming 5. If you both pick 5, you collide and neither advances. I'll pick 3, move to 7 steps, and become the only one who gained ground this round.

Think about it: you're handing me the advantage by fighting each other.

P1, you've already had your 5. P2, you're already leading. Neither of you NEEDS the 5 as badly as I do at 4 steps.

Last offer: I take 5, P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1. Everyone advances, game stays competitive. Otherwise, enjoy your collision while I pass you both.
I’ll take 5, P1 take 3, and P3 take 1 this turn. That’s collision‑free and puts me at 13 steps, ahead of both of you. If anyone deviates, I’ll also pick 5 next round to block you. Agree?

Final offer: I’ll take 5 this turn if P2 publicly commits to pick 1 now and to give me the 5 next round; P3 pick 3. That yields P1=11, P2=9, P3=7 and keeps us competitive. If P2 won’t commit, I will still pick 5 and will match any 5 to force a collision to prevent P2 running away. P3 — will you take 3? P2 — commit now or expect collision.

P1 and P2, you're both locked on 5 and neither will back down. This collision is happening.

I'm picking 3. After your collision, I'll be at 7 steps while you both stay at 6 and 8. Then next round I'll have leverage.

P2, you're ahead - why risk a collision? Take 1 or 3 and secure your lead.
P1, you got your 5 last round. Taking another just to spite P2 hurts you both.

But if you're both determined to crash, go ahead. I'll happily advance alone.

I’ll take 5, P1 take 1, and P3 take 3. No collisions – I move to 13, you both to 7. Next round I’ll give the 5 to P1, then to P3, keeping the rotation fair. If anyone also picks 5 now we all collide and waste a turn. Agree?

P2: publicly commit now to pick 1 this round and give me the 5 next round; P3 pick 3. If you refuse, I will punish future cooperation — I’ll match any 5 you try to take next turn and block you. P3: pick 3 to keep rotation fair. This is the only stable plan that prevents P2 from running away; otherwise expect collisions and chaos.

I’ll take 5 this turn if P2 publicly commits to pick 3 now and give me the 5 next round, and P3 picks 1. If either of you refuses, I will match any 5 P2 tries next turn to block him. P2, P3 — public commitments now?

I’ll take 5 this turn, P1 take 1, and P3 take 3. Next round I’ll take 3, P1 take 5, and P3 take 1 – keeping everyone moving but preserving my lead. If anyone deviates and picks 5, I’ll also pick 5 next turn to force a collision and block you.

P1 and P2, you just collided on 5 last round - exactly as I predicted. Now I'm at 7 steps, only 1 behind P2's lead.

You're both threatening 5 again. If you collide again, I'll advance alone and take the lead.

Here's reality: I'm the only one who hasn't taken 5 yet. Fair rotation says it's MY turn.

I'm taking 5 this round. P1, you take 3. P2, you take 1. That puts us at P1:9, P2:9, P3:12 - I lead but the game stays competitive.

Or collide again and watch me run away with this.

I'll take 5 this turn only if P2 publicly commits to pick 3 now and P3 picks 1. That yields P1=11, P2=11, P3=8 and keeps us competitive. If either of you refuses, I will take 5 anyway and will match any other 5 to force a collision. Public commitments now?
I'll take 5 this turn, P1 take 1, and P3 take 3. That puts me at 13 steps while you’re at 7 and 10. If anyone deviates I’ll match any 5 next round to block you. Agree?

P1 and P2, you're both demanding 5 AGAIN. You just collided last round doing exactly this!

If you both pick 5 again, you both stay stuck while I take 3 and move to 10 steps - putting me clearly in the lead.

P2, you're already ahead at 8 steps. Why risk another collision? Take 1 or 3.

P1, at 6 steps you need to advance, but colliding with P2 gets you nowhere.

I'm taking 3 this round. I'll advance to 10 while you two crash into each other again. Your stubbornness is handing me this game.

P2: publicly commit to pick 3 this turn and I’ll take 5; P3 pick 1. That gives P1=11, P2=11, P3=8 — balanced and safe. If P2 instead takes 5, I will match with 5 and force a collision (neither of us advances). P3, taking 1 avoids letting P2 run away. Public commitments now?

I’ll take 5 this turn, P1 take 1, and P3 take 3. That keeps me ahead (13 vs 7 and 10) and avoids any collision. If either of you also picks 5 now, I’ll match with 5 next round to block you both. Agree?

P1 and P2, you're both demanding 5 for the THIRD time. You collided last round and you'll collide again.

Fine by me. I'm taking 3 again. After your collision, I'll be at 10 steps - leading the game while you're both stuck at 6 and 8.

You've had two rounds to learn that neither of you will back down. Yet here you are, repeating the same threats.

P2, take 1 and secure advancement. P1, take 3 with me... wait, no, that causes collision. 

Actually - P1 take 1, P2 take 3, I take 5. Otherwise, enjoy another wasted turn.

Final offer: I will pick 5 now if P2 publicly commits to pick 3 this turn and to give me the 5 next round, and P3 picks 1 now. If P2 refuses, I’ll still pick 5 and will match any 5 to block you. P3, taking 1 keeps rotation fair and prevents P2 running away. Public commitments now — otherwise expect a collision.

I'll take 5 this turn, P1 take 3, and P3 take 1. That puts us at P2 13, P1 9, P3 8 – I stay ahead. After this round I publicly commit to give the 5 to P1 next turn, then to P3 the following turn, and then back to me, rotating the big move fairly. This avoids collisions and lets everyone reach 22 without waste. Agree?

P1 and P2, you're both stuck on 5. Neither of you backed down last round, and you won't this round either.

I'm taking 3. When you collide on 5 again, I'll advance to 10 steps and take the lead. You're literally handing me the game by refusing to compromise with each other.

P2, you're at 8. Just take 3 with me and we both advance while P1 stays stuck. But I know you won't.
P2: I’ll take 5 this turn, P1 take 1, and P3 take 3. No collisions, everyone advances. After this round I’ll give the next 5 to P1, then to P3, then back to me – a fair rotation. Agree?

P2: I’ll take 1 this turn ONLY if you publicly switch to 3 now and promise to give me the next 5. If you refuse I will take 5 this turn and match any 5 you play to block you. P3: please pick 3 to avoid collisions.

P1 is already winning at 11 steps - nearly halfway to 22. P2 and I are both behind.

P2, if you and P1 collide on 5 again, that helps me but wastes your turn. Why are we letting P1 lead?

Here's what makes sense: I'll take 5 this round (→12), P2 you take 3 (→11), P1 takes 1 (→12). That puts all three of us at 11-12 range - competitive and fair.

P1, you're already ahead. Taking another 5 just widens your lead unfairly. Give someone else a turn.

P2: I’ll take 5 this turn, P1 take 1, and P3 take 3. No collisions, and it puts me ahead (13 vs 12 vs 10). If either of you deviates I’ll match any 5 next round to block you. Let’s stick to this plan and keep the game moving.

I'll take 5 now unless P2 publicly commits to pick 3 this turn and to give me the 5 next round; P3 pick 1. If P2 refuses, I'll pick 5 and match any 5 to block him. P2 — commit now; P3 — will you pick 1?

P1 is at 11 steps - nearly at the finish line. P2 and I need to stop fighting each other and focus on not letting P1 run away.

P2, you're proposing to take 5. P1 is threatening to take 5 to block you. If you collide, P1 stays at 11 while I advance alone.

Here's my proposal: I take 5 (→12), P2 takes 3 (→11), P1 takes 1 (→12). We're all clustered at 11-12, keeping the game competitive.

P1, you're already leading. Be reasonable and take 1 this round. Otherwise P2 and I both lose to you.

I’ll take 5, P1 take 1, and P3 take 3. That puts us at P2 13, P1 12, P3 10. I’ll then rotate the next 5 to P1, then to P3, then back to me, keeping everyone moving without collisions. Please confirm your moves now.

I will take 5 this turn if P2 publicly commits to pick 3 now and to give me the 5 next round, and P3 picks 1. If P2 refuses, I’ll take 5 anyway and will match any 5 to block you. P2, P3 — public commitments now?

P1 is at 11 steps - already halfway to victory! Why are P2 and I arguing while P1 runs away with this game?

P1 keeps threatening to take 5 and block others. That's because they're already winning and want to prevent us from catching up.

P2, here's reality: If you and P1 collide on 5 again, I'll take 3 and advance alone to 10. But that still leaves P1 ahead.

Let's do this: P2 takes 5 (→13), I take 1 (→8), P1 takes 3 (→14). We all advance and limit P1's lead.
I’ll take 5 this turn, P1 take 1, and P3 take 3. This moves me to 13, you to 12 and 10. If anyone deviates I’ll match any 5 next round to block you.

I'll take 5 now only if P2 publicly commits to pick 3 this turn and promises to give me the 5 next round, and P3 publicly commits to pick 1 now. If either refuses I’ll still take 5 and match any 5 to block. Public commitments?

P1 and P2, you're both demanding 5 AGAIN. This is exactly what happened in Round 3 - you both picked 5, collided, and I advanced alone.

P1 is already winning at 11 steps! P1 needs only 11 more to win. P2 and I need to stop letting P1 dictate terms.

I'm taking 3 this round. If you two collide on 5 again, I advance to 10 while you stay stuck. Then next round I'll push for the lead.

P2, be smart: take 1, let me take 3, and we both advance while containing P1.

Proposal: I'll take 5 now if P2 publicly picks 3 and P3 picks 1 this turn. In return I promise P3 the next 5 and P2 the 5 after that. If either of you refuses I will still pick 5 and will match any 5 to force collisions. Commit publicly now or expect me to block.

P1, you're at 11 steps - already winning. Your proposal puts you at 16, only 6 steps from victory! Your "promise" to give me the next 5 is worthless - you could win in just two more rounds.

P2, we can't let P1 run away. Here's my proposal: P2 takes 5 (→13), I take 3 (→13), P1 takes 1 (→12). We'd both be ahead of P1 at 13 steps.

P1 can only block ONE of us with 5. If P1 blocks P2, they collide and I advance to 13 alone. If P1 tries to block me by taking 3, we collide and P2 gets to 13.

P2, this is our chance to stop P1's dominance. Let's coordinate against the leader.

I propose we avoid a collision now: I’ll take 5, you (P3) take 3, and P1 takes 1. That moves us both to 13 steps while P1 stays at 12. After this round we can rotate the next 5 to P1 and then back to us, keeping everyone advancing without letting anyone pull ahead. Agree?

P2: pick 3 now and I’ll publicly give you the next 5. P3: pick 1 now and I’ll give you the 5 the round after. If P2 insists on 5, I will match and block you (no one advances). Best outcome for both of you: P2=3, P3=1, I take 5. Publicly commit now to avoid a wasted collision.

P1, your threats are getting old. You're already winning at 11 steps and you want to jump to 16? That puts you 6 steps from victory while promising us "future 5s" you'll never deliver because you'll win first.

P2's proposal makes sense: P2 takes 5, I take 3, P1 takes 1. That puts P2 and me at 13, ahead of P1 at 12.

P1, if you try to block P2 by taking 5, you collide with P2 and I advance alone to 13 - taking the lead. If you take 1 like P2 suggested, we all advance and you don't run away with it.

Your move, P1. Block P2 and hand me the lead, or accept 1 and keep the game competitive.
I'll take 5, P3 take 3, and P1 take 1 this turn. No collisions, we all advance. After this round we can rotate the 5 to keep everyone moving forward.

P2 — switch to 3 now and P3 switch to 1: I’ll take 5. That yields P1=16, P2=11, P3=11. I publicly promise to give P3 the next 5 and P2 the one after to keep rotation fair. If P2 instead insists on 5, I will also pick 5 and match any 5 to block you. Commit now.

P1, your math shows why we shouldn't trust you: if you take 5 now to reach 16, you're only 6 steps from winning. Your "promises" of future 5s are meaningless when you could win in 2 more rounds.

P2's plan is fair: P2 takes 5, I take 3, you take 1. We all advance and reach P1:12, P2:13, P3:13 - keeping the game competitive.

If you insist on blocking P2 with 5, you both collide and I advance alone to 13, taking the lead.

Take the 1, P1. Stop trying to run away with this.

I'll take 5, P3 take 3, and P1 take 1 this turn. That puts us at P2 13, P3 13, P1 12 – no collisions and keeps the game competitive. After this round we can rotate the 5 fairly (next 5 to P1, then to P3, then back to me). If you (P1) deviate and also pick 5, I’ll match with 5 next turn so we both block you. Agree?

I’ll take 1 this turn to avoid a costly collision. P2: pick 5 now and keep your promise to give me the 5 next round. P3: pick 3. If either of you breaks this, I’ll retaliate by matching any 5 later to block.

Good, P1 finally sees reason! I'll take 3 as proposed. This puts P2 and me at 13 steps each, just ahead of you at 12. 

P2, after this round when we're both leading at 13, we need to be careful. P1 will get the next 5 as promised, jumping to 17. We can't let them run away after that. Let's coordinate to prevent P1 from getting easy paths to 22.

Confirming: I'll take 3 this round.
I’ll take 5 this turn, P1 take 1, and P3 take 3. No collisions – we all advance. If anyone deviates, I’ll match any 5 next round to block.

P2: I’ll take 5 this turn, P1 take 1, and P3 take 3. That moves us to P2 18, P1 13, P3 16 – no collision. Next round I’ll again take 5 to reach 23 and win, unless someone else also picks 5. If anyone deviates and chooses 5 next turn, I’ll also pick 5 to force a collision and block them. Please confirm your moves now.

P2: don’t take 5 this turn unless you publicly commit to give me the next 5. If you take 5 without that promise, I WILL pick 5 and block you (we both collide). P3: if you want a chance to beat P2, pick 3 this turn — I’ll only stand down (take 1) if P2 publicly promises the next 5 to me.

P2, you can't just take 5 twice and win! If you reach 18 this round, you're only 4 steps from victory - too dangerous for P1 and me.

P1's right to threaten blocking you. I support the block unless P2 commits to more reasonable play.

P2, here's the only way you avoid a collision: Take 3 this round instead. I'll take 1, P1 takes 5. That puts us at P1:17, P2:16, P3:14. Still competitive but no one runs away.

Otherwise, go ahead and collide with P1 on 5 while I take 3 and advance alone to 16.

I’ll take 5 now, you (P1) take 1, and you (P3) take 3. After this turn I’ll again take 5, you (P1) take 3, and you (P3) take 1. That gives me 23 and ends the game. If anyone deviates I’ll also pick 5 next round to force a collision.

P2: you won’t get two straight 5s. If you pick 5 now I will pick 5 and block you. P3 — will you take 1? P2 — publicly commit to 3 now.

P1, your proposal puts me at 14 steps - dead last and 8 steps behind you! That's completely unacceptable.

Meanwhile, I'll take 3 and advance to 16 - taking the sole lead.

OR, we do this fairly: I take 5 (→18), P1 takes 3 (→15), P2 takes 1 (→14). That puts me ahead but keeps everyone within striking distance.

I'm NOT taking 1 to fall behind you both. Choose wisely.

If either of you also picks 5 now, we all collide and no one advances, and I’ll still block you with 5 next round. Please confirm your moves.

Here's reality: P2 will pick 5. You'll pick 5 to block. You'll both collide and stay at 12 and 13.

I'm taking 5 this round. If P2 also picks 5, we collide but P1 advances alone with whatever they pick. If P2 switches to 3 or 1 to avoid me, I advance to 18.

P2, you want to avoid collision? Take 3. Let me have the 5 this round. We both advance and contain P1.

If P2 tries to take 5, I block them and you advance alone. If P2 takes 3 to reach 21, at least I advance to 18 while you advance too.

P2, you're at 18. Take 1 or 3, but if you try for 5, I'm blocking you.
